translated: The Buddha Speaks the Sutra of Immeasurable Pure and Equal Enlightenment, Scroll 4
Translated by Tripiá¹­aka Master Zhi Lou Jia Chan of the Later Han Dynasty from the Yuezhi Kingdom
The Buddha said to the bodhisattvas and others, If you are able to control your mind
and not do evil with your body in this world, this is a great virtue, the most incomparable in the eight directions and above and below.
Why is this so?
In the buddha-lands of the innumerable directions and above and below, the celestials and people all naturally do good, do not do much evil, and are easy to teach and transform.
Now I am a buddha in this world, in the midst of the five evils, five pains, and five burnings, and it is the most difficult.
I teach the people to end the five evils, to remove the five pains, and to remove the five burnings;
I subdue their minds and make them uphold the five good deeds, attain their blessings and virtues, and attain the path of liberation, longevity, and nirvana.
The Buddha said:ğŸ”½What are the five evils?
What are the five pains?
What are the five kinds of burning?
What are the five evils that should be eliminated and the five virtues that should be upheld?
What are the five virtues that, if upheld, will bring about blessings, longevity, and the path to nirvana that transcends the world?
The Buddha said:
The first evil is that all heavenly beings, people, and even down to birds and animals, insects and worms, want to do many evil things.

The strong oppress the weak, they turn against each other, kill each other, and devour each other. They do not know what is good, are rebellious and unrighteous, and receive their punishment. This is the natural way of the world, and one will go towards it.

The divine spirit records and remembers, and if one offends, it will not be forgiven. It continues on and on, and thus there are poor, lowly, begging, and orphaned people, and those who are deaf, blind, mute, foolish, vicious, and those who are mentally ill and incompetent.
Those who are noble, wealthy, talented, wise, and courageous are all due to their past lives, where they did good, were kind, filial, and practiced charity and virtue.

Therefore, there are official matters, royal laws, and prisons, but they are unwilling to fear and avoid doing evil and entering the law, receiving their faults, heavy punishments, and severe consequences, seeking to be liberated but finding it difficult to escape.

In this world, there are these present things before our eyes. After death, it is even more severe. Entering the dark and mysterious, receiving a body and being reborn, it is like the severe suffering and extreme punishment of royal law.

Therefore, there are naturally hells, animals, hungry ghosts, insects, flying creatures, and other kinds of beings that trade their forms, change their evil ways, and have different lifespans. The souls, lives, and essences naturally enter their destinies.
Receiving a form and relying on the womb, one is alone and encounters it, following each other and being born together, turning to repay each other, and should return to each other.
The calamities, evils, and punishments, and the many affairs that have not ended, one will never be able to leave.
Transmigrating through these realms, for countless eons there is no chance of escape, and liberation is difficult to attain, with pain beyond description.

Naturally, there is this between heaven and earth. Although it does not suddenly arrive, it always takes the natural way in a timely manner, and all should return to good and evil. This is a great evil, a great pain, a great burning.
The suffering is like this, with sorrow and lamentation, like a raging fire burning a person's body.

If a person can single-mindedly control their thoughts, be upright in body and conduct, do only good, and not do many evils, then they can alone attain liberation, obtain blessings and virtues, attain longevity, transcend the world, and attain the way of heaven and nirvana. This is a great good.
The Buddha said:
The second evil is that in the world, emperors, officials, people, fathers, sons, brothers, families, and couples have little righteousness and do not follow the laws and regulations.
They became licentious, extravagant, arrogant, and conceited, each wanting to have a good time, indulging their desires freely, teasing each other, not fearing death at all.
Their minds and words were different, their thoughts and speech were insincere, they were deceitful and not loyal, flattering and using clever words.
Their conduct was not upright, they envied each other, slandered each other, and fell into evil and injustice.
The ruler was not clear-minded, his heart did not discern, he employed ministers, and the ministers were in power.
Those of shallow understanding were able to act, knowing the situation, being in an improper position, being manipulated by them.

Falsely slandering the loyal and good, not in accord with the will of Heaven, greatly violating reason, ministers deceived their ruler, sons deceived their father, younger brothers deceived their elder brothers, wives deceived their husbands.
In the home, relatives and acquaintances continued to deceive each other, each harboring greed and lust, their hearts alone were angry, and their desire for more increased.
There are distinctions of noble and humble, high and low, but no male or female, no great or small, the mind is all the same, wanting to enrich oneself.
Ruining the family, losing the body, not caring about the past or future, the family and relatives are destroyed because of it.

Sometimes within the family, outside, among acquaintances, friends, and neighbors, the foolish people in the market turn to work together, harming each other in turn.ğŸ”½Competing for money and wealth, fighting, becoming angry and making enemies;
Competing for victory, the stingy and rich burn with worry;
Unwilling to give, stubbornly guarding and cherishing.

Loving treasures and being greedy, sitting and thinking about them, the mind is tired and the body suffers. In this way, in the end, there is nothing to rely on. Coming alone and going alone, not a single follower.

Good and evil, misfortune and blessings, calamities and punishments, chasing life to where it is born, either in a place of joy or entering painful poison, only then will one regret it, but what can be done about it?
Sometimes worldly people, with foolish minds and little wisdom, see goodness and slander it out of resentment, unwilling to emulate it.
They only want to do evil and create false laws;
They only want to steal and always harbor malicious thoughts;
They want to obtain others' wealth to use for their own needs, but it dissipates and is exhausted, and they seek again;
Their deviant minds are not upright, and they are always alone and fearful, fearing others' disapproval, not considering it at the time, and only regretting when it is too late.
In this world, they end up in prison, naturally heading towards their own misfortune.
In the world, there are poor, destitute, and orphaned people, who are only due to their disbelief in morality and virtue and unwillingness to do good in their previous lives.

In this world, they do evil, and the celestial spirits record it. When their lives end, they enter the evil paths, and there are naturally hells, animals, hungry ghosts, and all kinds of insects and worms.

Transmigrating within these, for countless eons, there is no chance of escape, and it is difficult to attain liberation. The pain is indescribable. These are the second two great evils, two pains, and two burnings.
The suffering is like this, as if a fire were burning a person's body.

If a person can, within this, single-mindedly control their thoughts, be upright in body and conduct, and solely do good without doing evil, then their body alone will be liberated, they will attain blessings and virtues, and they can attain long life, transcend the world, and attain the path to nirvana. These are the second two great goods.
The Buddha said:
As for the three evils, the people of the world are born together and rely on each other, living between heaven and earth. The lifespan cannot last for a few years.
There are those who are wealthy and noble, wise and good people;
below there are the poor and lowly, the weak and foolish;

in the middle there are those who are not good, who only think of poison and evil, whose body and mind are not upright, who always think of licentiousness, and are filled with worries in their chests;
Their desires entangled, they are restless in sitting and standing;
With greedy thoughts and stinginess, they only wish to obtain things without due cause;
They glance at beautiful women with evil expressions and licentiousness.
They despise their own wives and secretly engage in affairs, using the family's possessions to form illicit bonds, gathering for food and drink, and doing evil together.
They raise armies, become bandits, attack cities, fight, rob, kill, cut off, and forcefully take what is not theirs, seizing people's wealth.
They steal and obtain things without wanting to engage in honest work;
They are unwilling to do what they should seek;
With evil thoughts outside, they cannot focus on their work;
They want to achieve things by striking out, fearing that their power will be constrained, and take it back to support their families.
They live together, indulging their desires and enjoying themselves, indulging in pleasures to the fullest, and engaging in affairs with other people's wives.

They may even disregard the distinctions of close and distant relatives, elders, and the like, despised by the masses, and be a source of trouble and suffering to their families, both inside and outside.

They are also not afraid of county officials and legal orders, and have nowhere to avoid them. Such evil is recorded, and they naturally end up in prison. The sun and moon illuminate and recognize them, the divine spirits record them, and the various gods take them in.

Therefore, there are naturally hells, animals, hungry ghosts, insects, flying creatures, and wriggling creatures that revolve among them, generation after generation, for countless eons, with no chance of escape. It is difficult to attain liberation, and the pain is indescribable. These are the three great evils, three pains, and three burnings. The suffering is like a fire burning a person's body. If a person can single-mindedly control their thoughts, be upright in body and conduct, do only good, and not do evil, they will be able to liberate themselves, attain blessings and virtues, attain long life, transcend the world, and attain the path of nirvana. These are the three great goods.
The Buddha said:
The four evils are: evil people cannot do good, they destroy each other, they teach each other to do many evils together.
The ruler only wants to be a go-between, to slander, speak evil, scold, and lie, to be jealous and fight with each other.
They hate good people, destroy the virtuous, and delight in evil.
They are also unfilial and do not honor their parents, they despise teachers and elders, are untrustworthy and difficult to be sincere.
They claim to be noble and righteous, act arrogantly and violently, use force to oppress others, and do not know themselves.
They do evil without shame, think themselves strong, and make others serve and fear them.
They do not respect Heaven, Earth, the spirits, or the sun and moon, cannot be taught to do good, cannot be transformed, act recklessly, and think this is always right.
They also have no worries or sorrowful thoughts, and do not know fear. Indulging in arrogance like this, the devas take note.
Relying on some merit and virtue created in their previous lives, a little goodness supports and protects them.
In this life, they create evil, and their merit and virtue are exhausted. The good ghosts and spirits each leave them, and they stand alone, empty, with nothing to rely on.
They receive heavy misfortune and retribution. Their lifespan ends, and evil returns. Naturally pressed and hurried, they will go and be pursued, unable to stop.
Naturally, many evils gather and exhaust them. Their names and records are in the devas' place. Misfortune pulls and drags them, and they will encounter each other. They will go and head towards it.

Receiving excessive punishment, their bodies and minds are shattered. Their spirits and forms are extremely suffering, unable to escape. They can only move forward and enter the fiery cauldron.ğŸ”½At that time, what use is regret?
What can be done about it?

The Way of Heaven is natural, and one cannot stumble. Therefore, there are hells, animals, hungry ghosts, insects, flying creatures, and wriggling creatures. They revolve among these, generation after generation, for countless eons, with no chance of escape. It is difficult to attain liberation, and the pain is indescribable. These are the four great evils, four pains, and four burnings.
The suffering is like a fire burning a person's body.

If a person can, within this, single-mindedly control their thoughts, be upright in body and conduct, do only good, and not do evil, then their body alone will be liberated, and they will attain blessings and virtues. They can attain long life, transcend the world, and attain the Way of Heaven and nirvana. These are the four great goods.
The Buddha said:
As for the five evils, worldly people are lazy and unwilling to do good. They do not think about making a living, and their wives and children are hungry and cold, as are their parents.
When they want to scold and teach their children, the children have evil thoughts and glare with anger.
Their words cause disharmony, and their disobedience and rebellion are worse than wild people, like enemies, not like having no children.

They lie everywhere, borrowing from others, causing the multitude to suffer and detest them, and they are especially without gratitude, without a heart to repay. They become impoverished and destitute, unable to obtain anything again.
They compare and contrast sounds, indulging in play and wandering, frequently obtaining things for no reason, using them to provide for themselves, not fearing prohibitions.
They eat and drink to excess, drink alcohol and enjoy delicacies, coming and going without any sense of moderation.
They are rude and pushy, not understanding human feelings, staring and forcing others.
Seeing others happy, they hate and resent them.
Without righteousness or propriety, they act as they please, and cannot be admonished.

They also do not worry about their parents, wives, or children, whether they have anything or not. They also do not think of repaying their parents' virtue, nor do they think of their teachers' kindness.
Their minds always think evil, their mouths always speak evil, and they do not accomplish anything in a day.

They do not believe in the Way of Virtue, do not believe there are wise and sagely sages of the past, do not believe that doing good is the Way to attain liberation from the world, and do not believe there are Buddhas in the world.
They want to kill arhats and create schisms in the bhiká¹£u saá¹…gha, always wanting to kill people - wanting to kill their parents, brothers, wives, children, relatives, and friends.
Their parents, brothers, wives, children, relatives, and friends hate them and want them to die.

They do not believe the words of the Buddha's sÅ«tras, do not believe that human life ends in death, and that after death one is reborn again, do not believe that doing good brings good, and do not believe that doing evil brings evil.
Such men and women, their minds and thoughts are all like this, going against and rebelling, foolish and confused, angry and lustful, knowing nothing.
They think their own pleasure and goodness is great wisdom, and do not know where they came from or where they will go in life and death.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
They are unwilling to be kind and filial, and are evil and rebellious against Heaven and Earth. In the midst of this, they hope for good fortune, wishing to attain longevity and immortality.

They will inevitably return to the path of birth, death, toil, and suffering, and the ways of good and evil. The evil they have done will bring calamity and misfortune, and they will not be able to attain liberation.
They cannot be transformed to do good, and even if taught with kind words and guided on the ways of birth, death, good and evil, they will not believe it.
Even if one speaks with a compassionate heart, wishing to liberate them, it will not benefit them.
Their minds are closed off, and their thoughts are not open to understanding. When their great life is about to end, at that time they will all regret it.
When it is too late to regret it, what can be done?
If one does not plan for good in advance, what benefit is there when one is at the end?
Between Heaven and Earth, the five paths are distinct. Vast and mysterious, vast and boundless, they continue to pass on to each other.
Good and evil, poison and pain, one must bear them oneself, there is no substitute.
The way of nature follows one's actions, chasing one's life to where one is reborn, and one cannot be indulgent or abandon it.
Good people do good, following goodness, kindness, and filial piety, following joy to enter joy, following light to enter light;
Evil people do evil, following suffering to enter suffering, following darkness to enter darkness.
Who can know this?
Only the Buddha's insight.
Teaching and instructing the people, few believe and practice it, birth and death do not cease, and the evil paths are not cut off.

Thus, the world's people cannot be fully taught, so there are naturally hells, animals, hungry ghosts, and all kinds of crawling and flying creatures, revolving in them for life after life, for countless eons, with no chance of escape, difficult to attain liberation, and the pain is indescribable. This is the fifth great evil, the fifth pain, and the fifth burning.

The suffering is like a fire burning a person's body. If a person can single-mindedly control their mind, be upright in conduct, match words with actions, be sincere in what they do, speak truthfully, not waver in their mind or words, do only good deeds, and not do evil, then they can alone attain liberation, obtain blessings and virtues, attain longevity, transcend the world, and attain the path to nirvana. This is the five great wholesome deeds.
The Buddha told the Bodhisattvas such as Ajita:
I have told you all that the five evils and suffering in this world are like this, causing the five pains and five burnings to arise, and they arise from each other.
The people in the world are unwilling to do good, but want to do evil. Anyone who commits these evil deeds will all naturally have to go through them again and enter the evil paths.
Or in this life they will first suffer from illness, die, and not be able to be reborn, showing it to the multitude.
When their lives end, they enter into the most extreme suffering, with sorrow and pain so intense that they burn themselves and destroy each other.

In the end, they become enemies and harm and kill each other, starting from small beginnings and escalating to great hardship and distress. All this arises from greed for wealth and sex, unwillingness to practice patience and giving, each wanting to indulge themselves, with no more right or wrong, wanting to gain a reputation for strength, being pressed by deluded desires, and not being able to obtain what they think of in their minds, with resentment in their hearts.
Bound by wealth and sex, they have no liberation and do not know when to be content;
They are thick-skinned and argue over desires, without any reflection, completely lacking principle, and do not follow the right path.

Wealth, nobility, and glory bring temporary pleasure, but one is unable to practice patience or know how to give and do good deeds. Power lasts only a short while and then fades away with a bad reputation.
Sitting in hardship, after a long time it becomes extremely difficult, and there is no end to it naturally following.
The royal law is spread far and wide, and people naturally report to each other, cooperating with each other;
The net of laws and regulations is tightly woven, and those who violate it will be caught in it.
This has been the case since ancient times. It is truly lamentable and regrettable.
The Buddha said to the Bodhisattvas such as Ajita:
If there is a Buddha in the world, he will all have compassion and pity for them, and his majestic spirit will crush and move the various evil events to dissolve them.
Allowing them to abandon evil and do good, to discard their thoughts, and to uphold the sutras and precepts, none will not accept and follow them.

Practicing the sutra teachings, not daring to violate them, they will attain the path of transcending the world, becoming unconditioned and entering nirvana, which is joyful, good, supremely blissful, and extremely bright.
The Buddha said:
You heavenly beings, emperors, people, and future generations, having obtained the Buddha's teachings, should carefully contemplate them and be able to be upright and practice correctly within them.

The ruler is virtuous and leads by example, restraining and guiding those below him. He teaches and instructs the people, causing them to admonish and encourage each other to do good, to deliver and liberate each other, each to be upright and self-reliant, compassionate, and merciful, not to be negligent throughout their lives, to revere the sages, respect their parents, and be universally loving and understanding.
The Buddha's teachings and instructions should not be violated. One should be concerned with the path to liberation and nirvana in the world;
One should be concerned with cutting off birth and death, suffering and pain, and uprooting evil;
One should be concerned with severing the path of evil and suffering of the hells, animals, hungry ghosts, insects, flying creatures, and wriggling creatures;
One should delight in the Buddha's world, uphold the teachings of the sutras, and not dare to violate them.
The Buddha said:
If you want to do good, what is the most urgent?
You should be upright in your body, upright in your mind, upright in your eyes, upright in your ears, upright in your nose, upright in your mouth, upright in your hands, and upright in your feet.
You should be able to restrain yourselves and not act rashly. Keep your body and mind pure and harmonious.
Control yourselves internally and externally, do not follow desires, and do not commit any evil.
Always be gentle in speech and focused in action. Walk, sit, and rise without moving.
When doing things, you should first think carefully and plan them out. Assess your abilities, look at the overall goal, be stable, and do things slowly;
If you act hastily and do not think things through, your actions will not be accurate, you will lose your effort, and you will regret your failures later, suffering in vain and losing yourself.
Uphold sincerity and loyalty, and you will attain the Way and transcend.
The Buddha said:

If you do more good deeds, spread kindness and virtue, and do not abandon the precepts of the Way, be patient, diligent, single-minded, and wise, and continue to teach and transform each other, doing good and being virtuous,

Those who practice the Dharma of this sutra with a compassionate mind, single-mindedly observing the precepts and maintaining purity for one day and one night will surpass those who cultivate goodness for a hundred years in the Buddha Land of Immeasurable Purity.
Why is this so?
In the Buddha Land of Immeasurable Purity, all accumulate virtue and goodness, and everything is spontaneous. There are no evils as small as a hair.
The Buddha said:
Those who cultivate goodness for ten days and ten nights will obtain more blessings than the people in the Buddha lands of other directions who cultivate goodness for a thousand years.
Why is this so?

In the Buddha lands of other directions, everyone cultivates goodness. Those who cultivate goodness are many, and those who do evil are few. Everything is spontaneous, and without seeking or striving, one naturally obtains it;
Here, those who do evil are many, and those who do good are few. Without seeking or striving, one cannot obtain it.
It is because people can be upright and cultivate goodness themselves, and sincerely seek the Way that they can do so.
There is no natural abundance here, and one cannot provide for oneself. One must go out and seek, suffering and struggling to make a living.
They deceive and cheat each other, acting good or bad, and obtain wealth and property to provide for their wives and children.
Drinking bitterness and eating poison, exhausting the mind and suffering the body, in this way they reach the end, their minds not focused, wandering and uneasy.
If a person can be calm and do good, diligently cultivating virtue, then they can do so.
The Buddha said:

I have compassion for all of you, as well as the gods, emperors, and people. I teach them to do all good and not do evil, according to their abilities I bestow the Way upon them, and teach and guide them to practice it all.

Then the ruler leads the transformation and teaches goodness to his subordinates, the father teaches his son, the elder brother teaches his younger brother, the husband teaches his wife, the family inside and outside, relatives and friends, they turn to teach each other, doing good and cultivating the Way.

They revered the sutras and upheld the precepts, each being upright and self-disciplined. The higher and lower classes checked each other, with no distinction of high and low, male and female. They observed the precepts with purity and joy.
They harmoniously followed the principles of righteousness, encouraging kindness and filial piety, and mutually restrained each other.

Those who obtained the Buddha's sutras all held and contemplated them. They should not do what is wrong. If they commit an offense, they should repent. They abandoned evil and turned to goodness, discarded wrong views and embraced the right path. Hearing it in the morning, they changed in the evening. They upheld the sutras and precepts with such fervor as if a poor person had found a treasure.

Wherever the Buddha goes, in the counties and countries, he bestows the scriptures and precepts. The gods, sun, moon, stars, spirits, kings, ministers, officials, people, dragons, ghosts, hell beings, and animals all receive and practice them. Then the ruler reforms and becomes good. He fasts and contemplates with purity, rectifies his mind and practices correctly. He sits in his position with dignity, teaches the people to be good, and practices the prohibitions of the Way. His words are authoritative and his stops are orderly;
the ministers serve their ruler with loyalty and straightforwardness, receiving orders without daring to disobey.

The father and son speak with filial obedience and acceptance. Brothers, couples, relatives, friends, superiors and inferiors mutually order, speaking in accord and harmonizing principles. The superior and inferior, the elder and younger, respectfully serve each other, with propriety as righteousness, not contradicting each other. None do not reform the past and cultivate the future, purify the mind and change the practice, upright in the middle, naturally doing good, and obtaining what they wish.
The way of natural transformation in response to goodness, if one seeks immortality, one can attain longevity, if one seeks to transcend the world, one can attain the way of nirvana.
The Buddha said:
The majestic spiritual power of the Buddha is revered, and there is no evil that cannot be eliminated and transformed, and no one who cannot be liberated.

Now I have appeared in the world, in this evil world I have become a Buddha, with compassion and pity, teaching and guiding, the gods, emperors, ministers, officials, governors, and people, according to their desires and aspirations, all enabling them to attain the Way.

Wherever the Buddha goes, and through the prefectures, countries, counties, villages, and towns he passes through, there is no place that is not prosperous and well-supplied, with the world at peace, the sun and moon shining twice as bright as usual;
the wind and rain come at the right time, and the people are at ease;
the strong do not oppress the weak, and each finds their place.
There will be no evil years or epidemics, no one will be sick or weak, no wars will break out, the country will have no thieves or bandits, no grievances or oppression, and no one will be imprisoned.
The ruler, ministers, and people will all be joyful, loyal, kind, and sincere. Each will be self-disciplined, naturally guarding the country, harmonious, filial, and happy.
The rich and poor will share blessings and bestow kindness, their hearts joyful and loving each other. They will give away wealth and yield righteousness, humbly yielding first.

They will respect each other with propriety, like father and son, like elder and younger brother, all being benevolent and virtuous, harmonious and orderly, without any disagreement, and extremely happy.
The Buddha said:
I pity my children and want to deliver them, even more than parents love their children.

Now, the gods, emperors, people, and all crawling and flying creatures in the eight directions, above and below, who have obtained the Buddha's sutras and precepts, and who uphold the Buddha's Way, all attain wisdom, their minds are all enlightened, and none do not transcend suffering and attain liberation from worry and pain.

Now, I have become a Buddha in the midst of the five evils, five pains, and five burnings, and have subdued the five evils, exhausted the five pains, and completely eradicated the five burnings. Using goodness to conquer evil, I pull out the poison and suffering, enabling them to attain the five kinds of goodness and brightness, and burning evil does not arise.

After my nirvana, the sutra teachings will gradually be cut off. People will be deceitful and do many evils, no longer doing good. The five burnings will arise again, and the five pains will be severeâ€”returning to the previous methods, they will naturally return, and after a long time, they will become even more severe, beyond description. I have only told you a little bit about the Way.
The Buddha told the Bodhisattvas such as Ajita:
You should each contemplate and uphold it, and teach it to each other, just as the Buddha's sutras and precepts should not be violated.
The Bodhisattva Ajita knelt with palms joined and said:
What the Buddha has said is extremely painful. The suffering of worldly people is severe, just as you have said.
The Buddha has compassion for all and delivers them all, saying:
'Accept the Buddha's weighty teachings and request to pass them on to each other.'
We dare not violate them.
The Buddha told Ananda:
I have compassion for you, and want you all to see the country where the Buddha Amitabha and the Bodhisattvas and Arhats reside.
Do you wish to see it?
Ananda was overjoyed, knelt with palms joined and said:
I wish to see it all.
The Buddha said:
If you wish to see it, rise and put on your robe, face west and bow - towards where the sun sets - pay homage to the Buddha Amitabha, touch your head to the ground and say:
'Homage to the Buddha of Immeasurable Pure and Equal Enlightenment.
Ä€nanda said:
Yes, I accept the teaching.
He then got up, put on his outer robe, bowed to the west - the direction where the sun sets - and paid homage to the Buddha of Immeasurable Pure Light, touching his head to the ground and saying:
Homage to the Buddha of Immeasurable Pure and Equal Enlightenment.

Before Ä€nanda had even finished speaking, the Buddha of Immeasurable Pure Light emitted a great radiance and spiritual power that pervaded the countless buddha-lands in the eight directions and above and below. The heavens and earth all greatly shook.

The countless heavens and earth, Mount Sumeru, the precious mountains, the great precious mountains, the great and small world systems, the great and small hells within them, the mountains, forests, valleys, and dark places were all greatly illuminated, and a great rain of revelation fell.

Ä€nanda, the bodhisattvas, arhats, devas, emperors, and people all saw the Buddha Immeasurable and Pure Light, the bodhisattvas, arhats, and the country's seven treasures. Their minds were all greatly delighted and joyful. They all rose and bowed to the Buddha Immeasurable and Pure Light, touching their heads to the ground, and said:
We pay homage to the Buddha Immeasurable and Pure Light, the Perfectly Enlightened One.

After the Buddha Immeasurable and Pure Light emitted his light and spiritual power, countless devas, people, and all crawling and wriggling creatures all saw the Buddha Immeasurable and Pure Light's radiance. None were not kind-hearted, joyful, and doing good.

In all the hells, animal realms, and hungry ghost realms, and in all the places of punishment and suffering, they all ceased and were no longer punished. None were not liberated from their worries and suffering.
The blind could see, the lame could walk, the sick were cured, and the weak became strong.
The foolish became wise, the lustful and angry became kind and virtuous, and the poisoned were cured.
Bells, drums, lutes, harps, and musical instruments all sounded without being played.
Women's jewelry made sounds by itself.
All birds and animals cried out in joy.
At that time, there was none who did not rejoice and attain liberation.
At that time, the devas in the buddha-lands all held heavenly flowers and incense, descended into the sky, and made offerings to the buddhas and the Buddha Immeasurable and Pure Light.
The devas all spontaneously produced myriad kinds of music to delight the buddhas, bodhisattvas, and arhats.
At that time, the joy was indescribable.
The Buddha told Ä€nanda and the Bodhisattva A-yÃ­ and others:
When I speak of the Buddha of Immeasurable Pure Light, the bodhisattvas, arhats, and the naturally occurring seven treasures of his land, will there be any difference?
Ä€nanda knelt for a long time with his palms joined and said:
The Buddha's explanation of the land of the Buddha of Immeasurable Pure Light is excellent. It is exactly as the Buddha has said, not differing in the slightest.
The Buddha said:
